awd_abstract_narration:
The 2023 Midwest Optimization Meeting will be organized and hosted by the University of Michigan in fall 2023 to provide a regional opportunity for graduate students and early career researchers in optimization to communicate new findings and learn about new advances in the field. Optimization and control theory are among the major branches of applied mathematics which have important applications in science and engineering. This biennial conference will continue the tradition of providing a both educational and exchange opportunities for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior faculty to learn about the most recent advances and trends in optimization and control theory and their applications. 

The main objectives of the 2023 Midwest Optimization Meeting are to communicate recent advances and identify and develop trends in optimization, convex analysis, variational analysis, and computational mathematics as well as in applications such as machine learning and control domains. The meeting will embrace both theory and diverse applications of the field, with an intention to enrich graduate students’ perceptions of active research areas and open problems in optimization, as well as help to inform them of new future research directions and collaborations.  The conference is planned for two days with each day of the meeting consisting of plenary and contributed talks, engaging both leading experts as well as early career researchers. Details about the conference can be found on the conference website: https://emunix.emich.edu/~bwang/MOM2023/index.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The two-day 2023 Midwest Optimization Meeting (MOM 2023) has been organized and successfully held at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor on October 21-22, 2023.  The objectives of this meeting were to communicate recent advances and developments in optimization, convex and variational analysis, computational mathematics and in their applications such as to control, game theory, machine learning, and multi-disciplinary design optimization. The meeting embraced both theory and diverse applications of the field and enriched participants’ perception of active research areas and open problems in optimization and its applications. It has also helped inform new future research directions and collaborations.

 

The MOM 2023 has featured 5 plenary talks (50 min talk and 10 min for Q&A) by leading experts who have made significant recent contributions in these fields.  There were also 34 contributed talks (25 min talk and 5 min Q&A) organized in three parallel sessions by researchers and students who have been actively contributing to vibrant ongoing research in these fields. The 2023 MOM has facilitated many interactions between large numbers of researchers at different career stages both during the Q&A sessions after each talk and during the breaks spread out during both days.   

 

The first Midwest Optimization Meeting was organized at Western Michigan University in 1997 in order to bring the experts, young researchers, and graduate students from the nearby states, working in the field of optimization, optimal control and variational analysis, to meet and discuss the recent developments in the state of art of this rapidly growing subject. Since then, 23 meetings have been held in 13 different places in the Midwest. While historically the meeting has been a one-day event, MOM 2023 was held as a two-day event reflecting its growth in size and appeal.


Last Modified: 09/24/2024
Modified by: Ilya Kolmanovsky
